text:
I'm 4 years late to this thoughtful article which delves deeply into the dichotomy between involving users ("nothing about us without us") and progressing along learning curves ("making things better by making better things"); and the role technology can play in social change (as part of infrastructure, alongside laws, markets and social norms)

<https://ethanzuckerman.com/2016/06/22/the-worst-thing-i-read-this-year-and-what-it-taught-me-or-can-we-design-sociotechnical-systems-that-dont-suck|https://ethanzuckerman.com/2016/06/22/the-worst-thing-i-read-this-year-and-what-it-taught-me-or-can-we-design-sociotechnical-systems-that-dont-suck>

attachments.title: The worst thing I read this year, and what it taught me... or Can we design sociotechnical systems that don't suck? - Ethan Zuckerman
attachments.text: Note: Shane Snow wrote a long and thoughtful email to me about this post. While we agree to disagree on some substantive issues, primarily our thoughts about the future of VR, we also found quite a bit of common ground. He noted that my essay, while mostly about the ideas, strays into the realm of… Read More »The worst thing I read this year, and what it taught me… or Can we design sociotechnical systems that don’t suck?

elements.text: I'm 4 years late to this thoughtful article which delves deeply into the dichotomy between involving users ("nothing about us without us") and progressing along learning curves ("making things better by making better things"); and the role technology can play in social change (as part of infrastructure, alongside laws, markets and social norms)
https://ethanzuckerman.com/2016/06/22/the-worst-thing-i-read-this-year-and-what-it-taught-me-or-can-we-design-sociotechnical-systems-that-dont-suck

text:
Some raw material for a patchy map or periodic table about the role of technology in society:

• "Building apps instead of solving real problems" (emphasizes positive outcomes of tech capability)
• Accelerationism; progressing along learning/optimization curves (again emphasizes positives)
• Ensuring teams building tech are demographically balanced (emphasizes process)
• Ian Malcolm: "you were so busy seeing if you could, you didn't stop to think if you should" (emphasizes negative outcomes of tech capability)
• Facebook critiques; Tech should take responsibility for breaking things (again emphasizing negatives)
• Representation in dev teams of end users; "nothing about us without us"
Not sure this is going somewhere, but improvisation ("yes, and ..") most welcome.

elements.text: Some raw material for a patchy map or periodic table about the role of technology in society:
"Building apps instead of solving real problems" (emphasizes positive outcomes of tech capability)
Accelerationism; progressing along learning/optimization curves (again emphasizes positives)
Ensuring teams building tech are demographically balanced (emphasizes process)
Ian Malcolm: "you were so busy seeing if you could, you didn't stop to think if you should" (emphasizes negative outcomes of tech capability)
Facebook critiques; Tech should take responsibility for breaking things (again emphasizing negatives)
Representation in dev teams of end users; "nothing about us without us"
Not sure this is going somewhere, but improvisation ("yes, and ..") most welcome.

text:
Alan Kay on the context and catalysts of personal computing

<https://notionrealized.com/blog/alan-kay>

attachments.title: Alan Kay on the context and catalysts of personal computing
attachments.text: Alan Kay, or the “father of personal computers," is best known for his work on object-oriented programming languages, windowing graphical user interface design, and for leading the team that developed Smalltalk.
attachments.fallback: Notion: Alan Kay on the context and catalysts of personal computing

elements.text: Alan Kay on the context and catalysts of personal computing

text: "I think of civilization as being a set of processes trying to invent things that mediate, deflect, turn away, and modify most of the things that are wrong with our brain."

elements.text: "I think of civilization as being a set of processes trying to invent things that mediate, deflect, turn away, and modify most of the things that are wrong with our brain."

text:
Nice quick demo of a "tape drawing" UI, where you use one hand to control the position of the pen, and the other hand to control the angle, allowing for precisely drawing both smooth curves and straight line segments.

<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LvyzwN36PSw>

text: It's interesting that he says "we bring the computer to us, not us to the computer" but actually the user is still making quite a lot of allowances for the computer using floaty light pens with no tension between the hands. I wonder if it might be more bringing the computer to us to simply autofit bezier curves to a photo of the physical tape drawing.

elements.text: It's interesting that he says "we bring the computer to us, not us to the computer" but actually the user is still making quite a lot of allowances for the computer using floaty light pens with no tension between the hands. text: <@UDQBTJ211> my interpretation was that ‘bringing the computer to us’ emphasizes human embodied skills by letting us adjust the curve ‘inputs’ / parameters at the speed of thought using our hands! Auto-fitting bezier curves to me feels like going back to treating the computer as a magical black box again instead of having both human and computer participate in the process :smile:

text: Alan Kay , he is one of my Heros regarding Computers, but he doesn't dare to go beyond his own culture ( how could he?). He is aas far as one could get from a technical/industrial perspective regarding progressive thinking related to technology.

elements.text: Alan Kay , he is one of my Heros regarding Computers, but he doesn't dare to go beyond his own culture ( how could he?). He is aas far as one could get from a technical/industrial perspective regarding progressive thinking related to technology.

text: Yet you won'T seem him debate: What is progress? What is technology? - outside of the western civilization narrative, like say for example from an indigenous perspective like mentioned here: <https://www.goodreads.com/en/book/show/45449501-sand-talk>

attachments.text: This remarkable book is about everything from echidnas to evolution, cosmology to cooking, sex and science and spirits to Schrödinger’s c...

text: Thus he would always look for the _right_ kind of progress, the _right_ kind of technology. Non technology or non progress are non existent in his worldview.

text: Lots of things could be said about this interview, I'll try one more thing: Alan implies many things things like the superiority of writing over oral information exchange or even dialog. There actually people, kind of reinventing dialog. They created a whole bunch of language to talk about certain aspects about the phenomenon of dialog in communication. Really interesting stuff ( cognitive science, If you are interested in that, which I highly recommend, you may search for: John verveake awakening from the meaning crisis)

text: Yes, it does. I just needed to go back and reread <http://viznut.fi/texts-en/permacomputing.html>

text:
What I mean was if you consider two input devices; the [light pens+screen+projector], and [physical tape+whiteboard+camera], then to me the second one makes better use of human's embodied skills because you can feel the tension between your hands, more intuitively peel off and re-stick mistakes etc. (it does have downsides such as creating waste).

The motivating problem they identified in the video was how to digitise the tape images. In 1999 this maybe required inputting the data digitally in the first place (with hand tools), but nowadays you could also have the option of inputting the data with a camera. The end result is the basically the same; users can draw on the wall with their hands, but end up with a vector image on the computer system.

elements.text:
What I mean was if you consider two input devices; the [light pens+screen+projector], and [physical tape+whiteboard+camera], then to me the second one makes better use of human's embodied skills because you can feel the tension between your hands, more intuitively peel off and re-stick mistakes etc. (it does have downsides such as creating waste).

The motivating problem they identified in the video was how to digitise the tape images. In 1999 this maybe required inputting the data digitally in the first place (with hand tools), but nowadays you could also have the option of inputting the data with a camera. The end result is the basically the same; users can draw on the wall with their hands, but end up with a vector image on the computer system.

text: I agree that black boxes are bad. You wouldn't want to be in a situation where the image on the computer is not what you drew, with no way to understand where you and the computer are disagreeing.

elements.text: I agree that black boxes are bad. You wouldn't want to be in a situation where the image on the computer is not what you drew, with no way to understand where you and the computer are disagreeing.
